title: Hustlers costume secrets: Jennifer Lopez’s mishap and bonding in the strip club
text:
Those Hustlers outfits slayed (Picture: STXfilms)

Aside from their incredible pole dancing skills, the ladies of Hustlers wowed us with their fabulously noughties-inspired wardrobe.

From the glitter to barely-there g-strings and those ridiculously chunky high heels, the audience have been pretty much in awe over the costumes worn by Jennifer Lopez, Constance Wu and their strip club cohorts.

Hustlers, which is hotly-tipped for Oscar nominations FYI, centers on a dancer called Ramona who ropes in a group of her fellow strippers to start a side hustle swindling Wall Street bankers out of their money.

There’s enough action to keep us entertained for 90 minutes but, let’s face it, the outfits make it so much more glamorous.

Metro.co.uk spoke to Hustlers costume designer Mitchell Travers to get the lowdown on how those incredible costumes came to life behind-the-scenes.

‘I was excited by the scripts initially, because I there weren’t a tremendous amount of film references for me, you know, often, you know, you get hired on a movie and it’s in the 80s or the 60s, there’s so much in terms of films that you can reference,’ Mitchell said.

‘So for me, it was really exciting that there wasn’t something like that to turn to, and that we might be one of the first few films that have helped to create an identity for this time in history.’

Oh, the drama (Picture: Barbara Nitke/STXfilms via AP)

If you’ve seen Hustlers, then you’ll know that the introduction to Ramona’s character might just be one of the most jaw-dropping yet.

Jennifer, 50, gets straight to work showing us exactly what she spent months training for, dazzling us with her pole dancing skills.

But oh, that g-string bodysuit.

It looked incredible but Mitchell reveals there was a major mishap behind-the-scenes which sent the team racing in to save the actress’ modesty.

‘It’s my nightmare. And it happens,’ Mitchell says of wardrobe malfunctions on movie sets.

‘The first take of the first shot that we did of Jennifer coming out for her entrance, two of the strings popped off her body. So I ran in with my team, there was about four of us stitching her back into this costume on the stage because we just knew it’s not something that we could risk and so we had to completely sew her into that bodysuit that you see on camera,’ Mitchell revealed.

He quipped: ‘There’s really not a ton of coverage so there’s more double stick tape involved in that movie probably more than any other movie.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

With the nature of the movie – women dancing in strip clubs wearing very little clothing – Mitchell made it a priority to design outfits which the cast were comfortable with.

He explained: ‘Obviously, there is a level of nudity in the movie that requires some confidence building and understanding what the women prefer about their bodies or areas that they’re not as confident in.

‘We just really tried to work with them in the privacy of their trailer and in the fitting room so that we could understand the movement that they were going to do with change the costume and make sure that everybody felt comfortable with the level of coverage or nudity depending on the scene.’

Throughout the film, we see Jennifer in an array of skimpy outfits from lace to feather and everything in between.

‘Jennifer wears a lot of bold looks in the film and they needed to behave in different ways,’ the designer explained.

‘Some of them on the pole, some of them in the champagne room, some in the locker room. So for me, it was just an understanding of the differences in lighting between all of those setups, and also the differences in terms of where the Ramona character was in the evolution of her story.

Ramona and Destiny’s style couldn’t have been more different (Picture: Capital Pictures)

Mitchell worked his magic on the Hustlers costumes (Picture: STX Films)

‘Of course I’m no fool, I read the script and I understand that Jennifer is going to be introduced to the audience in this extremely provocative way and in a way that we’ve never seen Jennifer before.’

Advertisement

Mitchell recalls how he broke the ice with the cast by heading to strip clubs before production even began so he could get an idea of the looks he wanted to create for the characters.

He revealed: ‘We were patrons and we tried to understand as much about the culture as we could, and really immerse ourselves into the lifestyle and into the community so that we could portray their lives accurately, it was always important to us that this didn’t become – there was no judgment in our portrayal of these women.’

Mitchell joked that while it’s not the ‘traditional process’ of bonding with your new colleagues, it ‘definitely made for fast friendships’.

‘It was really a bonding experience for so many of us. And ultimately, listen, I’m not the average patron at a strip club,’ he recalled fondly.

‘But I immediately found so much common ground with the with the women working there, and they were so giving of their time and their stories.

Cardi B was a ‘delight’ thanks to her knowledge of strippers (Picture: STK Films)

‘The women that I worked with were, were really interested in being portrayed in the more complex light than I think film has traditionally treated the exotic dancer or stripper or sex worker.’

And then there’s Cardi B.

Before the glitz and glam of the rap scene, the Bodak Yellow rapper made her living as a stripper in New York.

So who better than Cardi to turn to for advice on that?

Advertisement

‘Cardi was a complete delight for me, she was a total surprise and that she was really ready to take this on as an actress and not as a global superstar in the way that we’ve come to know her,’ Mitchell revealed.

‘I asked her as much as I could. I told her I wanted to get her into that mindset about the Cardi before we got to know her, and what she was like in the clubs.

‘We had a lot of conversations about how her life has changed and how we could help get her back into that frame of mind.

‘Her insight was actually quite important to me in terms of costume design for this film.’

Sounds like quite the experience.

Hustlers is out in cinemas now.
